When the good man who cultivates samÄdhi and exhausts the aggregate of perception, his ordinary dreams and thoughts are extinguished, and he is always one in sleep and wakefulness. His enlightened mind is empty and still, like a clear sky, and he no longer has the coarse and heavy shadows of the dusts of the external world. He observes all the worlds, the great earth, rivers, and mountains, like a mirror reflecting clearly, coming without sticking, and going without a trace. He receives illumination in vain, and clearly understands the traces of past habits. There is only one pure truth. The root source of birth and death is revealed from this. He sees the twelve types of beings in the ten directions, exhausting their categories. Although he has not yet understood the course of each individual's life, he sees the same basis for birth, like a mirage, flickering and clear, serving as the ultimate pivot of the floating faculties and objects. This is called the domain of the aggregate of formation.

If the flickering and clear fundamental nature of this is the nature entering the originally clear and still, and the habitual tendencies of the one clear and still are like waves ceasing and transforming into still water, it is called the exhaustion of the aggregate of formation. This person is then able to transcend the turbidity of sentient beings.
Observing its source, it is based on the hidden and concealed false imagination.

Ananda, you should know that when these good men and women who have attained right knowledge and samatha have a mind that is clear and correct, the ten kinds of celestial demons will not find an opportunity to disturb them. They will be able to thoroughly investigate the origin of the class of beings, and in the midst of that origin, the source of life will be revealed. Observing that profound, clear, and perfectly moving origin, and in the midst of that perfect source giving rise to speculation, these people will fall into the two theories of no cause.
First, these people see the original absence of a cause.
Why is it so?

Because these people have completely broken through the mechanism of life and, riding on the eight hundred merits of the eye faculty, see the sentient beings in the past eighty thousand eons, their karmic flow circling like a bend in a river, dying here and being born there. They only see sentient beings cycling in that place, and beyond eighty thousand eons it is dark and they cannot see anything. They then form this understanding:
'These sentient beings in the worlds of the ten directions have existed without a cause for the past eighty thousand eons.'
Based on this speculation, they lose right and universal knowledge and fall into heterodox ways, deluding the nature of bodhi.
Second, this person sees the end without a cause.
Why is it so?

This person, having seen the root of birth, knows that people give birth to people, birds give birth to birds, crows have always been black, swans have always been white, humans and gods are upright by nature, animals are horizontal by nature, white is not made by washing, black is not created by dyeing, and for 80,000 eons there is no change or alteration. Now, exhausting this form is also like this. I originally did not see bodhi, how could there be the matter of attaining bodhi?
Know that today all things and forms are originally without a cause.
Because of this speculation, they lose right and universal knowledge, fall into non-Buddhist paths, and confuse the nature of bodhi. This is called the first non-Buddhist theory of no cause.

Among these samÄdhis, good men who concentrate on the correct mind and do not give the demons an opportunity, who investigate the origin of the class of beings and observe the eternally clear and constantly disturbed source, and who give rise to speculation within the perfect and eternal, fall into the four theories of universal permanence.
First, this person exhausts the nature of mind and objects, and the two places have no cause.

Cultivating and being able to know the twenty thousand eons, the sentient beings in the ten directions who are born and perish all circulate without ever being scattered or lost, considering it to be permanent.
Second, this person exhausts the origin of the four great elements, and the four natures are always present.

Cultivating and being able to know the forty thousand eons, the sentient beings in the ten directions who are born and perish all have a fundamentally constant substance without ever being scattered or lost, considering it to be permanent.

Third, this person exhausts the six sense faculties, the manas consciousness that grasps and holds, and the fundamental original place of the mind consciousness. Because the nature is always constant,

cultivating and being able to know the eighty thousand eons, all sentient beings circulate without loss, originally always present and exhausting the nature of not being lost, considering it to be permanent.

Fourth, this person, having exhausted the source of thought, finds that the principle of life no longer flows or stops, and the thought of birth and death has now been eternally extinguished. In principle, it naturally becomes unborn and unceasing, and they calculate this as permanence based on the mind's understanding.

Because of this calculation of permanence, they lose right and universal knowledge and fall into non-Buddhist paths, confusing the nature of enlightenment. This is called the second non-Buddhist theory of establishing permanence.

Moreover, among those good men and women in samÄdhi, with a firm and correct mind, the demons find no opportunity. Exhausting the basis of the class of life, observing that the eternally disturbed and moving source is in oneself and others, those who give rise to speculation fall into four inverted views, a theory that one part is impermanent and one part is permanent.

First, this person observes the wondrous and bright mind pervading the ten directions, and takes this quiescent state as the ultimate divine self. From this, they reckon that the self pervades the ten directions, is clear and still, and does not move. All sentient beings are born and die within their own mind, so the nature of their mind is called permanent, while that which is born and perishes has a truly impermanent nature.

Second, this person does not observe their own mind, but observes the lands in the ten directions, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges. Seeing places where the eon is destroyed, they take this as the ultimate impermanent nature, while places where the eon is not destroyed they take as the ultimate permanence.

Third, this person separately observes their own mind, which is refined, subtle, and secret, like a tiny particle, flowing through the ten directions with no change in nature, able to cause this body to be born and perish. The indestructible nature they take as the permanent nature of the self, while all birth and death flowing out from the self they take as the impermanent nature.

Fourth, this person knows that the aggregate of perception is exhausted and sees the flow of the aggregate of formations. The constantly flowing aggregate of formations is considered to be of a permanent nature, while form, perception, and conception, which have now ceased, are considered to be impermanent.

Because of this calculation, one part is impermanent and one part is permanent, so one falls into a non-Buddhist path and is deluded about the nature of enlightenment. This is called the third non-Buddhist theory of partial permanence.

Again, among those good men in samÄdhi, with a firm and correct mind, the demons cannot take advantage. Exhausting the basis of the class of life, observing that the eternally disturbed and moving origin is profoundly clear, in the midst of the divisions, those who give rise to calculations fall into the four theories of having boundaries.

First, this person calculates that the source of life flows and is unceasing. Calculating the past and future is called having boundaries, and calculating the continuous mind is called having no boundaries.

Second, this person observes the eighty thousand eons and sees that before the eighty thousand eons, sentient beings are silent and unseen. The place of no hearing and seeing is called having no boundaries, and the place where there are sentient beings is called having boundaries.

Third, this person calculates that their all-pervading knowledge attains boundless nature, and that all these people are presently within their knowledge, but they have never known the knowing nature of those [people], and are called those who do not attain the boundless mind, but only have a limited nature.

Fourth, this person exhausts the emptiness of the aggregate of activity, and with their observed mind's path of reasoning, in the body of all sentient beings, they calculate that all are half born and half extinguished, and clarify that all that exists in the world is half existent and half nonexistent.

Based on this calculation of existence and nonexistence, they fall into the external paths and confuse the nature of enlightenment. This is called the fourth externalist who establishes a theory of existence and nonexistence.

Moreover, among those good men in samÄdhi, with firm and correct minds, the demons cannot take advantage. Exhausting the basis of the class of life, observing that eternally clear and constantly disturbed origin, in the midst of knowledge and views, those who give rise to calculations fall into four kinds of inversions, falsely claiming immortality and making false arguments.
First, this person observes the source of transformation and change, seeing the place of transition and change as change, seeing the place of continuity as constant;
seeing the place of seeing is called birth, not seeing the place of seeing is called cessation;
the place where the nature of the cause of continuity is unbroken is called increase, and the place where the middle is separated in the midst of continuity is called decrease;
each place of birth is called existence, and the place where each disappears is called nonexistence.
Observing with principle, using the mind to see separately.
When a person seeking the Dharma comes to ask about its meaning, he answers:
I am now both born and extinguished, both existent and nonexistent, both increasing and decreasing.
At all times, he confuses their words, causing the person in front to lose the chapters and sentences.

Second, this person observes their mind, and in the place where each is nonexistent, they attain realization through nonexistence. When someone comes to ask, they only answer with one word, saying only nonexistence, and apart from nonexistence, there is nothing else to say.

Third, this person observes carefully that each mind has a place and a cause for attainment. When someone comes and asks, they only answer with the word is, saying it is this or that, and nothing else.

Fourth, this person sees both existence and nonexistence. Because their realm is divided, their mind is also confused. When someone comes and asks, they answer that it is both existent and nonexistent, but within nonexistence it is not also existence. All their evasive and confused statements cannot withstand thorough investigation.

Based on this, they falsely imagine and confuse, falling into external paths and deluding the nature of enlightenment. This is called the fifth external path with four inverted natures, the false and confused empty discourse of immortality.

Moreover, among those of the samÄdhi, all good men, with firm and correct minds, the demons cannot take advantage. Either solidifying one's body, saying form is me;

All of them speculate that there is a form after death. In this way, there are sixteen forms in the cycle. From this delusion, they speculate that the two natures of ultimate affliction and ultimate enlightenment are equally driven, each not touching the other.

They see that form is extinguished and has no cause for shape;
